symbols.doc: The symbols used in the schema to specify e.g. dimensions of arrays.

symbol.name: n_points
symbol.doc: Number of discretization points inside the fitting region.

field.name: label
field.doc: Human-readable label for this fit procedure.

field.name: region
field.doc: Subset of the independent axis for this fit procedure.

group.name: peak_PEAK
group.doc: One spectral peak of the peak model. It is envisioned that peaks are labeled as peak_0, peak_1, and so on.

field.name: total_area
field.doc: Total area under the curve. (can also be used for the total area minus any background values.)

field.name: relative_sensitivity_factor
field.doc:
Relative sensitivity for this peak, to be used for quantification in an NXprocess.
As an example, in X-ray spectroscopy could depend on the energy scale3 (see position), the ionization cross section, and the element probed.

field.name: relative_area
field.doc:
Relative area of this peak compared to other peaks.
The relative area can simply be derived by dividing the total_area by the total area of all peaks or by a more complicated method (e.g., by additionally dividing by the relative sensitivity factors). Details shall be given in fitting_method

group.name: area_constraint
group.doc: Constraint on the minimum and maximum area of this peak.

field.name: depends_on
field.doc: Link to a peak the area constraint depends on.

group.name: width_constraint
group.doc: Constraint on the minimum and maximum width of this peak.

field.name: depends_on
field.doc: Link to a peak the width constraint depends on.

group.name: position_constraint
group.doc: Constraint on the minimum and maximum position of this peak on the abscissa.

field.name: depends_on
field.doc: Link to a peak the position constraint depends on.

group.name: background_BACKGROUND
group.doc: One fitted background (functional, position, and intensities) of the peak fit. It is envisioned that peaks are labeled as background_0, background_1, and so on.

field.name: fitting_method
field.doc: Description of the method used to optimize the parameters during peak fitting. Examples: - least squares - non-linear least squares - Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm (damped least-squares) - linear regression - Bayesian linear regression

field.name: envelope
field.doc:
Resulting envelope of all NXpeak instances.
Should have the same dimension as the `position` axes of the individual peaks.

field.name: figure_of_merit_METRIC
field.doc:
Figure-of-merit to determine the goodness of fit, i.e., how well the peak model fits the measured observations.
This value (which is a single number) is oftenused to guide adjustments to the fitting parameters in the peak fitting process.

attribute.name: metric
attribute.doc: Metric used to determine the goodness of fit. Examples include: - :math:`\Chi^2`, the standard deviation of the residuals - reduced :math:`\Chi^2`:, :math:`\Chi^2`: per degree of freedom - :math:`R^2`, the coefficient of determination

field.name: residual
field.doc: Difference between the envelope and the data to be fitted.
